WebBrowserArray Class

Definition

Provides a control array of WebBrowser controls

In this Article

[System.ComponentModel.ProvideProperty("Index", typeof(System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser))]
[System.Obsolete("Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.* classes are obsolete and supported within 32 bit processes only. http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=160862")]
public class WebBrowserArray : Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray, System.ComponentModel.IExtenderProvider

Remarks

The WebBrowserArray class provides an equivalent for the run-time functionality of a Visual Basic 6.0 WebBrowser array. It does not provide the design-time features of a Visual Basic 6.0 control array.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Constructors

WebBrowserArray()

Initializes a new instance of the WebBrowserArray class.

public WebBrowserArray ();

Remarks

When you instantiate a WebBrowserArray, you must also call the SetIndex method to create the initial element in the array.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Initializes a new instance of the WebBrowserArray class, specifying its container.

public WebBrowserArray (System.ComponentModel.IContainer Container);
Container
IContainer

The IContainer where the control array will be hosted.

Remarks

When you instantiate a WebBrowserArray, you must also call the SetIndex method to create the initial element in the array.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Properties

Item(Int16)

Gets a specific element of a WebBrowserArray by index. Read-only.

public System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser this[short Index] { get; }
Index
Int16

A Short that specifies the position of an element of the control array.

Value
WebBrowser

A WebBrowser at the specified Index in the control array.

Remarks

The Item property is the default property for a control array. Therefore, the following lines of code are equivalent. 

MsgBox(CStr(WebBrowserArray.Item(1).Text))  
MsgBox(CStr(WebBrowserArray(1).Text))
Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Methods

CanExtend(Object)

Gets a value that determines whether a control is a member of a WebBrowserArray.

public bool CanExtend (object target);
target
Object

A WebBrowser control.

Returns
Boolean

true if target is a member of the control array; otherwise false.

Remarks

The CanExtend method can be used to determine whether a specific WebBrowser control is the base element of the control array from which the other elements were cloned.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Remarks

o
Object

An Object.

Remarks

This method cannot be called from your application's code. Use AddHandler to hook up events for any controls that are added by using the Load method.

The ResetIndex method is not supported in the WebBrowserArray class.

public void ResetIndex (System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser o);
o
WebBrowser

A Control.

Remarks

This method is not supported, and calling it does not raise an exception.

Note

SetIndex(WebBrowser,Int16)

Sets the index of the initial WebBrowser in a WebBrowserArray.

public void SetIndex (System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser o, short Index);
o
WebBrowser

A WebBrowser in the control array.

Index
Int16

A Short that represents the index of the specified WebBrowser.

Remarks

The SetIndex method should only be called when you are creating the initial element in the control array. To add subsequent elements, call the Load method and specify the Index.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

ShouldSerializeIndex(WebBrowser)

Returns a value that indicates whether a WebBrowser is a member of this WebBrowserArray.

public bool ShouldSerializeIndex (System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser o);
o
WebBrowser

A WebBrowser in the control array.

Returns
Boolean

true if o is a member of this control array; otherwise, false.

Remarks

If the specified WebBrowser is a member of a different WebBrowserArray, ShouldSerializeIndex returns false.

Note

DocumentCompleted

Occurs when the WebBrowser control finishes loading a document.

public event System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowserDocumentCompletedEventHandler DocumentCompleted;

Remarks

The WebBrowser control navigates to a new document whenever one of the following properties is set or methods is called:

  • Url
  • DocumentText
  • DocumentStream
  • Navigate
  • GoBack
  • GoForward
  • GoHome
  • GoSearch

    Handle the DocumentCompleted event to receive notification when the new document finishes loading. When the DocumentCompleted event occurs, the new document is fully loaded, which means you can access its contents through the Document, DocumentText, or DocumentStream property.

    To receive notification before navigation starts, handle the Navigating event. Handling this event lets you cancel navigation if certain conditions have not been met, for example, when the user has not completely filled out a form. Handle the Navigated event to receive notification when the WebBrowser control finishes navigation and has begun loading the document at the new location.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Navigated

Occurs when the WebBrowser control has navigated to a new document and has begun loading it.

public event System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowserNavigatedEventHandler Navigated;

Remarks

The WebBrowser control navigates to a new document whenever one of the following properties is set or methods is called:

  • Url
  • DocumentText
  • DocumentStream
  • Navigate
  • GoBack
  • GoForward
  • GoHome
  • GoSearch

    Handle the Navigated event to receive notification when the WebBrowser control has navigated to a new document. When the Navigated event occurs, the new document has begun loading, which means you can access the loaded content through the Document, DocumentText, and DocumentStream properties. Handle the DocumentCompleted event to receive notification when the WebBrowser control finishes loading the new document.

    You can also receive notification before navigation starts by handling the Navigating event. Handling this event lets you cancel navigation if certain conditions have not been met, for example, the user has not filled out a form.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Navigating

Occurs before the WebBrowser control navigates to a new document.

public event System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowserNavigatingEventHandler Navigating;

Remarks

The WebBrowser control navigates to a new document whenever one of the following properties is set or methods is called:

  • Url
  • DocumentText
  • DocumentStream
  • Navigate
  • GoBack
  • GoForward
  • GoHome
  • GoSearch

  • You can handle the Navigating event to cancel navigation if certain conditions have not been met, for example, when the user has not completely filled out a form. To cancel navigation, set the Cancel property of the WebBrowserNavigatingEventArgs object passed to the event handler to true. You can also use this object to retrieve the URL of the new document through the Url property. If the new document will be displayed in a Web page frame, you can retrieve the name of the frame through the TargetFrameName property.

    Handle the Navigated event to receive notification when the WebBrowser control finishes navigation and has begun loading the document at the new location. Handle the DocumentCompleted event to receive notification when the WebBrowser control finishes loading the new document.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

NewWindow

Occurs before a new browser window is opened.

public event System.ComponentModel.CancelEventHandler NewWindow;

Remarks

The WebBrowser control opens a separate browser window when the appropriate overload of the Navigate method is called or when the user clicks Open in New Window on the browser shortcut menu when the mouse pointer hovers over a hyperlink. You can disable the shortcut menu by setting the IsWebBrowserContextMenuEnabled property to false.

The NewWindow event occurs before the new browser window is opened. You can handle this event, for example, to prevent the window from opening when certain conditions have not been met.

For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

ProgressChanged

Occurs when the WebBrowser control has updated information about the download progress of a document that it is navigating to.

public event System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowserProgressChangedEventHandler ProgressChanged;

Remarks

You can use a handler for this event to implement a navigation progress bar similar to the one in Internet Explorer. Use the CurrentProgress property to determine the number of bytes that have been downloaded successfully. Use the MaximumProgress property to determine the total number of bytes available for downloading.

For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Resize

Occurs when the control is resized.

public event EventHandler Resize;

Remarks

To determine the Size of the resized control, you can cast the sender parameter of the EventArgs data to a Control and get its Size property (or Height and Width properties individually).

To handle custom layouts, use the Layout event instead of the Resize event. The Layout event is raised in response to a Resize event, but also in response to other changes that affect the layout of the control.

For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Validated

Occurs when the control is finished validating.

public event EventHandler Validated;

Remarks

When you change the focus by using the keyboard (TAB, SHIFT+TAB, and so on), by calling the Select or SelectNextControl methods, or by setting the ActiveControl property to the current form, focus events occur in the following order:

Enter GotFocus Leave Validating

Validated

LostFocus

When you change the focus by using the mouse or by calling the Focus method, focus events occur in the following order:

Enter GotFocus LostFocus Leave Validating

Validated

If the CausesValidation property is set to false, the Validating and Validated events are suppressed.

If the Cancel property of the CancelEventArgs is set to true in the Validating event delegate, all events that would usually occur after the Validating event are suppressed.

For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework.
